facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 345, 347 to 349 of 1971 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 345 347 to 349 of 1971. Appeals from the judgment and decree dated the

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and decree dated February 5, 1970 of the Punjab Haryana High Court in C.W. Nos. 3627/68, 273, 274 and 1380 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated the February 5, 1970 of the Punjab Haryana High Court,in C.W. Nos. 3627/68, 273, 274 and 1380 of 1969.

facts.text: Land measuring 165 acres including the appellants' land measuring 6 bighas, 4 biswas and 17 biswasi in Piru Banda within Ludhiana Municipal limits was acquired.

anchor.surface_text: Land measuring 165 acres including the appellants land measuring 6 bighas, 4 biswas and 17 biswasi, companyprised in various khasra numbers situated in the revenue estate of Piru Banda within the municipal limits of Ludhiana Municipal Committee,

facts.text: Land acquired for Model Town Extension Scheme No.1 by Ludhiana Improvement Trust.

anchor.surface_text: was acquired for a development scheme of the Ludhiana Improvement Trust  hereinafter called the Trust  styled as Model Town Extension Scheme No.1.

facts.text: Notification under section 36 of the Punjab Town Improvement Act published on September 16, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: A numberification under section 36 of the Punjab Town Improvement Act  hereinafter called the Improvement Act , which is analogous to section 4 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894  hereinafter called the Acquisition Act  was published on September 16, 1960.

facts.text: Land Acquisition Collector, Improvement Trust, Ludhiana made award on March 31, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Land Acquisition Collector, Improvement Trust, Ludhiana, made his award on March 31, 1964, with regard to the said land.

facts.text: Appellants and other landowners made applications under section 18 of the Land Acquisition Act for reference to Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the said award the appellant and other land owners made separate applications under section 18 of the Acquisition Act for making a reference to the Tribunal companystituted under the Improvement Act  hereinafter respondent No. 2 .

facts.text: Cases referred to Tribunal (respondent No. 2), which delivered common judgment on October 16, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The cases were then referred to the Tribunal. The second respondent took up all the references together and delivered a companymon Judgment on October 16, 1968.

facts.text: Collector classified land into belts A, B, C at Rs. 60/-, Rs. 40/-, Rs. 20/- per square yard.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector had earlier classified the land acquired under three categories, namely, belt A, B and C fixing the price for valuation at the rate of Rs. 60/- Rs. 40/- and Rs. 20, - 100 9 per square yard respectively.

facts.text: Tribunal modified award for appellant in C.A. No. 345/1971: belt C raised to Rs. 30/- per sq yd, belt B upheld.

anchor.surface_text: The, Tribunal in the case of the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 345 of 1971 under discussion, modified the award to the extent that the price of the land companyprised in belt C was raised from Rs. 20/- to Rs. 30/- per square yard while the price for the area companyered by belt B was upheld.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Punjab and Haryana High Court challenging Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the order of the Tribunal by a writ petition in the High Court of Punjab and Haryana.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition following earlier decision and granted certificate under Article 133(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court following an earlier decision dismissed the writ petition. The High Court, however, granted a certificate to appeal to this Court under article 133 1   a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants claimed Section 59(a) of Punjab Town Improvement Act, 1922 is ultra vires Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The questions that are raised in these appeals by certificate by Mr. B. Sen on behalf of the appellants are these - Section 59 a  of the Punjab Town Improvement Act, 1222  Punjab Act 4 of 1922  is ultra vires article 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Tribunal did not apply uniform rate of compensation to different appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal took absolutely a wrong principle into companysideration in determining the companypensation of the lands acquired. The Tribunal has number applied its own rule as to the rate of companypensation uniformly to the different appellants.

facts.text: Punjab Town Improvement Act is Punjab Act 4 of 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Punjab Act 4 of 1922  is ultra vires article 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: By section 59 of Improvement Act, Land Acquisition Act applied with modifications.

anchor.surface_text: However, it is admitted that by section 59 of the Improvement Act the Acquisition Act is made applicable with certain modifications for the purpose of acquiring land for the Trust.

facts.text: Section 59(a) deems Tribunal not court for section 54 of Acquisition Act; 59(d) makes Tribunal award final.

anchor.surface_text: It is pointed out that by section 59 a  of the Improvement Act the Tribunal is number deemed to be the companyrt under the Acquisition Act for the purpose of section 54 of the latter Act and under section 59 d  the award of the Tribunal is deemed to be the award of the companyrt under the Acquisition Act and shall also be final.

facts.text: Tribunal considered only sale deeds prior to September 16, 1960 notification, ignored post-notification sales.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen submits that the Tribunal has taken into account only the sale deeds that have been produced in, the cases executed prior to the date of the numberification under section 36, namely, September 16, 1960. ,According to companynsel the Tribunal also took into account sale deeds executed within five years before that date but refused to take into companysideration the sale deeds executed after the said date of numberification.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Section 59(a) not violative of Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Acquisition of land under the Improvement Act admits of a reasonable basis of classification and section 59 a  is, therefore, number violative of article 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal did not adopt wrong principle by ignoring post-notification sales.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has, therefore, number adopted any unreasonable principles in ignoring the sales that have taken place after the date of numberification under section 36.

facts.text: Supreme Court did not interfere with quantum of compensation as no gross injustice shown.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the third and last submission of the appellants we are unable to interfere with the quantum of companypensation when numbercase of gross injustice and discrimination has been made out on the facts and circumstances taken into account by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Material date for compensation is publication date of section 36 notification: September 16, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification under section 36 in the pre- 1 0 12 sent case being of September 16, 1960, that is the material date which should be reckoned for purposes of determining companypensation.

facts.text: Tribunal consists of President qualified as High Court Judge and two assessors.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 60 the Tribunal shall companysist of a President and two assessors land the President shall be a person qualified for appointment as a Judge of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana.

issues.text: Whether Section 59(a) of the Punjab Town Improvement Act, 1922 (Punjab Act 4 of 1922) is ultra vires Article 14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: The questions that are raised in these appeals by certificate by Mr. B. Sen on behalf of the appellants are these - Section 59 a  of the Punjab Town Improvement Act, 1222  Punjab Act 4 of 1922  is ultra vires article 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal took a wrong principle into consideration in determining the compensation of the lands acquired?

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal took absolutely a wrong principle into consideration in determining the compensation of the lands acquired.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal has not applied its own rule as to the rate of compensation uniformly to the different appellants?

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has not applied its own rule as to the rate of compensation uniformly to the different appellants.

arguments.claim: Article 14 does not abhor reasonable classification if rational relation to object

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that article 14 does not abhor a reasonable classification provided the basis of the classification has a rational relation to the object to be achieved by the Act.

arguments.claim: Acquisitions under Improvement Act form distinct category due to scheme requirements and pre-acquisition procedure

anchor.surface_text: Here the object of the Improvement Act being improvement of the towns covers a specific, though a wide, field as may be evidenced by the elaborate provisions for preparation and implementation of schemes by the Trust under the said Act.

arguments.claim: s.59(a) not violative of Art 14 as reasonable basis of classification

anchor.surface_text: Acquisition of land under the Improvement Act admits of a reasonable basis of classification and section 59 a  is, therefore, not violative of article 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Denial of appeal right not violation of Art 14; Tribunal is qualified under s.60

anchor.surface_text: Again denial of the right of appeal available in the case of acquisition under the Acquisition Act does not make section 59  a  ultra vires article 14 of the Constitution. The Improvement Act constitutes a Tribunal with two assessors, unlike in the Acquisition Act.

arguments.claim: Finality of Tribunal award under s.59(d) to avoid delay in schemes

anchor.surface_text: The legislature by making the order of the Tribunal final under section 59 d  seeks to avoid delay in the course of litigation to defeat the purpose of the schemes framed under the Act.

arguments.claim: Right of appeal is creature of statute, denial not infringement of fundamental right

anchor.surface_text: Right of appeal is a creature of the statute and mere denial or taking away of such a right under the law cannot be considered as an infringement of a persons fundamental right.

holdings.text: Acquisition of land under the Improvement Act admits of a reasonable basis of classification and section 59(a) is, therefore, not violative of article 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Acquisition of land under the Improvement Act admits of a reasonable basis of classification and section 59 a  is, therefore, number violative of article 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification for acquisitions under Improvement Act has rational nexus to town improvement objectives, differing procedure and purpose from general LAA acquisitions; Tribunal qualified, finality avoids delay; appeal right statutory not fundamental.

holdings.text: The Tribunal has not adopted any unreasonable principles in ignoring the sales that have taken place after the date of notification under section 36.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has, therefore, number adopted any unreasonable principles in ignoring the sales that have taken place after the date of numberification under section 36.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Material date for market value is publication of s.36 notification (analogous to s.4 LAA), as modified by Schedule para 10; post-notification sales reflect speculation and inflated potentiality.

holdings.text: Unable to interfere with the quantum of compensation when no case of gross injustice and discrimination has been made out on the facts and circumstances taken into account by the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the third and last submission of the appellants we are unable to interfere with the quantum of companypensation when numbercase of gross injustice and discrimination has been made out on the facts and circumstances taken into account by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of gross injustice or non-uniformity warranting interference with Tribunal's rates after review of facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per s.23 LAA as modified by PTI Schedule para 10, market value at s.36 publication date.

holdings.text: Right of appeal is a creature of the statute and mere denial or taking away of such a right under the law cannot be considered as an infringement of a person's fundamental right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory appeal rights not fundamental; denial justified for expedition in town schemes.
